overview.historicalContext: Erdős Problem #607 from erdosproblems.com. Originally offered with a prize of $250.
overview.problemStatement: For a set of n" role="presentation" style="position: relative;">nnn points P⊂R2" role="presentation" style="position: relative;">P⊂ℝ2P⊂R2P\subset \mathbb{R}^2 let ℓ1,…,ℓm" role="presentation" style="position: relative;">ℓ1,…,ℓmℓ1,…,ℓm\ell_1,\ldots,\ell_m be the lines determined by P" role="presentation" style="position: relative;">PPP, and let A={|ℓ1∩P|,…,|ℓm∩P|}" role="presentation" style="position: relative;">A={|ℓ1∩P|,…,|ℓm∩P|}A={|ℓ1∩P|,…,|ℓm∩P|}A=\{\lvert \ell_1\cap P\rvert,\ldots,\lvert \ell_m\cap P\rvert\}. Let F(n)" role="presentation" style="position: relative;">F(n)F(n)F(n) count the number of possible sets A" role="presentation" style="position: relative;">AAA that can be constructed this way.
